G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Since the entry of the 2015 Judgment, there has been a substantial and material change in the parties’ and child’s circumstances, such that modification of the prior custody and parenting plan is necessary to serve the best interests of the minor child. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; *Schuh v. Schuh*, 458 Mass. 1 (2010).

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 31, the rights and responsibilities of parents regarding custody and visitation are to be determined “in accordance with the best interests of the child.”

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31; G.L. c. 215, § 3; and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction provisions of G.L. c. 209B, because the prior custody and parenting orders were issued by this Court and the child has resided in Massachusetts for more than six months preceding the filing of this Complaint.

G.L. c. 209B.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31; G.L. c. 215, § 3; and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction provisions of G.L. c. 209B, because the prior custody and parenting orders were issued by this Court and the child has resided in Massachusetts for more than six months preceding the filing of this Complaint.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court because the prior Judgment/Order regarding custody and parenting time was entered in this Division, and the parties and minor child presently reside within this Court’s jurisdiction. See G.L. c. 215, § 3; G.L. c. 223A, § 3.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: In determining custody and parenting-time issues, the Court has broad equitable powers to fashion orders necessary to protect the welfare of the child. See G.L. c. 215, § 6; *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. at 710–11; *Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. at 409–10.

*Schuh v. Schuh*, 458 Mass. 1 (2010).proposition: Since the entry of the 2015 Judgment, there has been a substantial and material change in the parties’ and child’s circumstances, such that modification of the prior custody and parenting plan is necessary to serve the best interests of the minor child. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; *Schuh v. Schuh*, 458 Mass. 1 (2010).
*Schuh v. Schuh*, 458 Mass. 1 (2010).case_name: FANEUIL INVESTORS GROUP, LIMITED PARTNERSHIP v. Board of Selectmen of Dennis
*Schuh v. Schuh*, 458 Mass. 1 (2010).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modification of child custody and parenting plans under G.L. c. 208, § 28, requiring a substantial and material change in circumstances in the best interests of the child. Schuh v. Schuh, 458 Mass. 1 (2010), as provided here, is a land-use and property/mortgage/title case involving a town’s reverter clause and has nothing to do with divorce, custody, parenting plans, or § 28. It therefore does not support the claimed custody-modification proposition and appears to be an erroneous or inapposite citation.
*Schuh v. Schuh*, 458 Mass. 1 (2010).relevant_excerpt: This case concerns a parcel of land (land) owned by the town of Dennis (town). The board of selectmen (board) deeded the land to the Dennis Housing Authority (authority) so that affordable housing could be constructed. The deed contained a reverter clause that prohibited a conveyance or transfer of the land without the consent of the board.... Because we conclude that the judge did not err, and agree with the judge that the plaintiff does not have a valid mortgage on the land, we affirm the decision of the Land Court.

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u.proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a custody or parenting-time order may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment, and (2) that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child. See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183–84 (2006); *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 710–11 (1985) (best interests paramount).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u.support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a general custody/parenting-time modification case. The court discusses that relocation requires a showing that removal is in the child’s best interests and notes ALI Principles stating that relocation can be a substantial change in circumstances, but it does not articulate or adopt the two-part standard that any modification of custody or parenting time generally requires (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances and (2) best interests of the child. The claimed proposition therefore overreads Mason’s holding and context.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents … shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a custody or parenting-time order may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment, and (2) that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child. See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183–84 (2006); *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 710–11 (1985) (best interests paramount).
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the standard for *modifying* an existing custody or parenting‑time order (material and substantial change plus best interests). Yannas is a relocation/custody case decided in the context of the original divorce judgment, interpreting the removal statute and articulating that best interests of the child are paramount and how they are assessed. It does not address the threshold requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances for modification of an earlier judgment, so it does not support that part of the proposition, though it is accurate authority for the ‘best interests paramount’ concept in relocation/custody analysis.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined…. Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”}

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.proposition: Emily is now ten (10) years old, significantly older than when the 2015 Judgment entered, and her developmental needs, social life, school responsibilities, and emotional capacities have changed markedly since age four. See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843–44 (2003) (recognizing developmental changes and child’s evolving needs as relevant); *Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406, 409–10 (1976).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Custody of Kali for “recognizing developmental changes and a child’s evolving needs as relevant.” This opinion is primarily about the best-interests standard, statutory factors under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and the importance of continuity and stability in custody, not about a child’s developmental changes over time as a basis for modification. The passages focus on preserving existing arrangements and the status quo, not on the significance of a child aging from four to ten or similar developmental shifts, so it does not clearly support the specific proposition stated.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.” (439 Mass. at 843).

*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406, 409\.proposition: Emily is now ten (10) years old, significantly older than when the 2015 Judgment entered, and her developmental needs, social life, school responsibilities, and emotional capacities have changed markedly since age four. See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843–44 (2003) (recognizing developmental changes and child’s evolving needs as relevant); *Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406, 409–10 (1976).
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406, 409\.support_reasoning: Vilakazi deals with an initial custody award for a three‑year‑old and articulates the general best‑interests standard, including consideration of the child’s present and probable future welfare. It does not discuss developmental stages, age‑related changes, or how a child’s evolving needs over time can justify modifying an earlier custody judgment. Thus it does not specifically support the proposition about the significance of a child aging from four to ten and corresponding developmental changes; that concept comes from Custody of Kali, not Vilakazi.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406, 409\.relevant_excerpt: “In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and the wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the child in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future, and it is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.” 371 Mass. at 409.

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 599\.proposition: While a child’s preference is not controlling, Massachusetts law recognizes that a mature child’s stated wishes constitute a significant factor in determining best interests. See *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 599–600 (1996); *Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 227–28 (1998).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 599\.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that the preference of an eleven-year-old child is not decisive but is a factor to be considered in custody determinations, and remands with a suggestion that, given the child’s increased age, the judge may appropriately interview him again regarding his preference. This directly reflects the principle that a child’s wishes are not controlling yet are a significant component of the best-interests analysis, especially as the child matures.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 599\.relevant_excerpt: “Although the boy was described in testimony as ‘a really bright student,’ we note that the preference of an eleven-year-old is not given decisive weight, although it is a factor to be considered. See Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595, 602 (1981); Baird v. Attorney Gen., 371 Mass. 741, 753 (1977); Bellotti v. Baird, 443 U.S. 622 (1979); Stone v. Duffy, 219 Mass. 178, 182 (1914); Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 617 (1987). As almost three years have gone by… it may be appropriate for the judge to interview the child again as to his preference….”

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 227\u.proposition: While a child’s preference is not controlling, Massachusetts law recognizes that a mature child’s stated wishes constitute a significant factor in determining best interests. See *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 599–600 (1996); *Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 227–28 (1998).
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 227\u.support_reasoning: The excerpts from Adoption of Hugo reproduced here do not discuss a child’s stated preferences or wishes at all; Hugo was four years old and the opinion focuses on weighing competing adoptive placements, sibling relationships, and stability, not on the child’s own views. The court’s best-interests analysis is framed entirely in terms of expert testimony, developmental needs, and relative capacities of caretakers, without mentioning any role for a mature child’s preference. On this text, Hugo does not provide authority for the proposition that a mature child’s wishes are a significant factor in the best-interests determination.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 227\u.relevant_excerpt: Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The “best interests of a child” is a question that presents the trial judge “with a classic example of a discretionary decision.” Adoption of a Minor (No. 2), 367 Mass. 684, 688 (1975).

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: For purposes of Massachusetts law, the totality of these changes—Mother’s completion of school, stable employment with regular hours, suitable housing with a bedroom for the child, the child’s older age and changed developmental needs, the strengthening of the mother‑child bond, Emily’s expressed desire for more time with Mother, and the emotional impact of the current schedule—constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances since the 2015 Judgment. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; *Schuh v. Schuh*, supra; *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 900 (1981).
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion in Bouchard does not address what constitutes a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28. Instead, it concerns the standards for making an initial custody award and emphasizes that custody determinations must be based on the child’s welfare and consideration of all relevant factors. It therefore cannot be cited as authority that a set of post‑judgment changes (education, employment, housing, child’s age, etc.) amount to a material change since an earlier judgment.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”
